segments.text: and a member of the Special Forces.
He has an opening statement he would like to make about what he will answer and what he won't answer.
John?

Okay, one of the conditions for me doing this interview is that I don't have to engage in any conversation or discussion about any particular combat experiences that I had in Vietnam, but I'm perfectly willing to discuss anything else.
Okay.
How's that?
Does that make sense?
It's fine.
Okay.
I guess the first thing I need to know is when did you go into the military?
I went in the Army in 1966, right after I got out of high school.
I enlisted in the Army in, I guess, June of 1966 under a kind of a delayed enlistment program, and I went in in September of 1966.
Why did you enlist?
I didn't have very many options, I guess.
That's one reason why I enlisted was because I didn't do very well in high school.
My family didn't have a lot of money, so they couldn't send me to college.
And I had the idea that if I went into the Army, you know, I could get the veterans' benefits, and then maybe somehow by proving myself, you know, I could get into college.
Another reason was simply just the idea of going in the Army sort of
fascinated me.
I just sort of wondered what it would be like.
When I enlisted initially, I enlisted for three years, and I didn't know really what the Army was all about.
I just knew I wanted to jump out of airplanes.
So I enlisted in the Army, what they call airborne unassigned, which meant like a dummy.
I hadn't picked a job that I was going to do in the Army.
The recruiter never told me that you're supposed to have a job.
I thought I was just going to, you know, get up in the morning and jump out of airplanes.
And I didn't find out until after basic training, when they assigned me to military police training, that you had to have a job, you know, in the Army.
When you joined, it was like June 1966 in Maricopa.
Yeah.
was starting to really become aware of Vietnam and where it was.
What was your feeling towards America's involvement in Vietnam at the time?
Well, I had a pretty clear idea that I thought that it was a legitimate involvement that, I guess, the duly constituted government of South Vietnam was being undermined, I guess, by

revolutionaries and I guess insurgents from the North, and that they had a legitimate right to call upon powers that had similar ideas, I guess democratic principles, to come to their assistance and to keep them from being denied what at that time I considered to be their rightful and
and justifiable political system.
So I saw it as legitimate.
Our involvement specifically in Vietnam is legitimate and just.
And I continue, as a matter of fact, to hold that idea to this very day.
Back to your initial joining of the military.
You joined in, you said, June of 66.
Right.
What was it like for a high school kid, fresh out of wherever, to just join the military and know that, in all likelihood, he was going to get sent to fight?
Well, to tell you the truth, I didn't.
I never had the idea of, in all likelihood, I was going to be sent to fight.
That's just sort of an overall, kind of an unfocused, impressionistic idea.
you know, going in the military.

Because again, I came from a fairly, I don't want to say disadvantaged background, but for guys in my social status, I guess, going into the Army was a typical thing that, you know, high school counselors for years and years had advised to people like myself and other, and my friends and things.
So it was really like a lot of the wealthier kids or the upper class kids, it was expected that they would go on to college.

it was more or less expected, you know, that the kids that didn't come from a wealthy background or hadn't majored in courses that would lead to a college education would either take some sort of a job or go into the military.
So it was kind of like, it was almost sort of like I was just following a pattern that most people in my group followed.
So it wasn't sort of like I, you know, I sat down and I consciously said,
I'm going to go in the Army, you know, and I'm going to find out.

It was just sort of like it was one of the options that I had open to myself, and my, you know, my uncles had done it, you know, and older kids in the neighborhood had done it, and they'd come back with their uniforms on and all that kind of stuff.
So it was just sort of an expected or a potential or a historical option that kids from my part of the country and my, I guess, social and economic status took for themselves.
You grew up in New Jersey?
Yeah, right near New York, about 12 miles from New York City.
Beautiful place.
Sounds like it was.
When you first joined, where were you sent?
I was sent to Fort Dix, New Jersey, for basic training.
First I went to Newark, New Jersey, where they swore me in, you know, and uphold the Constitution and stuff like that.
But I remember the first thing that happened to me.
After I was sworn into the Army, some guy started yelling at me.
And I had to clean up.
Clean up your own.
Clean up the place where we had all been sworn in.
The first thing they did was hand me a broom and said, clean up this place, private.
I said, well, geez, I guess this is, I'm in the Army now.
How did you get involved with the Special Forces?
Well, like I said, I enlisted in the Army airborne on a sign.
All that I knew is I wanted to jump out of airplanes.
I saw these pictures of guys coming out of airplanes.
I said, gee, that's hot stuff.
So anyway, they assigned me to military police.
And there was no way in the world, you know, a kid growing up in the streets of New Jersey, the last thing you want to be is a cop, right?
But I think they figure, you know, that if you've been on the edge of crime all your life, you know, that you have some insight, you know, into the criminal mind.
And plus I was big, you know, like six foot two or three and big, you know, and I liked all of the things.
I think I was a little bit more intelligent than your average guy, but I liked the same kind of things that your average, I liked the outdoors, you know, and all that sort of stuff.
But if you weren't real bright and you liked the outdoors and you liked to hunt and all that sort of stuff, they put you in the infantry.
But if you're fairly smart, you know, and you like the outdoors and you like to hunt and all that stuff, they put you in the military police.
But I didn't want to be in the military police.
So after I finished basic training, I went to military police training in Fort Gordon, Georgia.
And somewhere in
As I was going through the training and I'm marching around going, M-I-L-I-T-A-R-Y-P-O-L-I-C-E, I'm going, I don't want to be this.
I don't want to direct traffic or whatever you do.
And I had this friend, this crazy friend that I met there who was going to go to jump school too.
And one day he said, hey, there's this thing called special forces that
that you can volunteer for and you can get out of the military police.
And I had kind of a vague idea, I think, of what it was all about, but I didn't really have that clear of an idea.
He said, it's a lot of fun.
You still get to jump out of airplanes.
You get to do all kinds of hiking around in the woods and all that sort of stuff.
So me and two other guys one day went and took this test from a special forces recruiter.

Or somebody, I'm not sure, I can't actually remember whether he was in Special Forces or not, but we took this test where we had to, oh, they gave us these hypothetical scenarios and you had to tell them what you'd do in those situations.
One is if you got captured behind enemy lines and you had, you know, they gave you alternative ways of escaping, you know, which one would you choose, I guess.
And then they had another one that had to do with reconnaissance, where they'd show you a picture, and then you'd have to look from a point of view.
They'd give you points of view pictures, and you had to decide from what point of view that picture was taken.
And I think they had something on foreign language, and then another thing that had to do with flying helicopters.
I have no idea what that had to do with anything.
But anyway, that's sort of how I came to volunteer.
kind of an alternative to being in what I consider to be sort of a ridiculous job, you know, being a cop.
Once you got into them, you didn't stay at Fort Dix, I'm sure.
No, see, I went from Fort Dix, like I said, to Fort Gordon for military police training.
Then I went from Fort Gordon to jump school at Fort Benning.
And I didn't find out until I finished jump school at Fort Benning whether I was
was accepted to go into Special Forces training.
And it was the last day of jump school after we'd done all our jumping and had our wings and all that stuff.
They gather everybody in a big crowd.
And this sergeant stood up on a box and started reading off where everybody was going.
And most of the guys were going to the 173rd Airborne in Vietnam right at that point.
And I kept waiting for him to call my name.
And then I called off about, I guess, 10 or 20 names.
and said, oh, you were going to Fort Bragg, North Carolina for Special Forces training.
And I thought, oh my God, you know, here we go.
So I went from Fort Bending, Georgia to Fort Bragg, North Carolina for Special Forces training.
Now, my dad was also in the Special Forces, and he was stationed in Fort Bragg.
Was Fort Bragg more or less the headquarters for the Special Forces training?
Special Forces training, and there were
two Special Forces groups there, the Seventh Special Forces, I can't even remember, the Seventh and I don't know, the Third, I think, Third Special Forces.

And then they had what they called Special Forces Training Group, which was, Special Forces was situated on what they called Smoke Bomb Hill at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, and we were down the road from the 82nd Airborne.
which they called the animals or something like that.
They were viewed as sort of criminals and swine, people who were sort of misfits and weirdos.
82nd Airborne, what did they call it?
AA was their symbol.
It stood for All-American, and I think we changed that into something like animals and assholes.
But the worst thing that could happen would be to
bomb out of Special Forces training and end up going to the 82nd airport.
I mean, that was like the worst possible thing that you could imagine.
What did your training in Special Forces involve?
What did they teach you?
Well, the training I went through, it was called Tactics and Techniques, Phase I and Phase II.
God, it's hard to remember.
Phase I, Phase I we learned
I think phase one involved learning our job specialty that we were going to have within Special Forces.
Years was?
I was a radio operator called O5B.
My MOS in the Army was O5B4S.
When we first got there, we went through some processing where we had pictures taken from passports and all kinds of crazy stuff.

And then you just kind of went through a building and you, they didn't really tell you one way or the other, you know, what the difference, you knew that you could be, if you were E3 or E2 to E4, which is private to like a corporal, the options open to you were radio operator, engineer, and medic.
And if you were like E5 and above,
I think the options were all of those.
Those three plus, you could get into weapons, demolition, what they called operations and intelligence, which was more or less spying.
And I guess that was about it.
So anyway, first part had to do with training in the job.
I can't remember whether, though, in the first part there were some of the infantry tactics and guerrilla tactics.
Oh, yeah, yeah, that's right.

Part of it, the first part, you went through your MOS training, which for me involved learning everything about radios, cutting antennas to frequency, learning Mars code, learning radio procedure, learning about all the different kinds of radios, to the point where I could supposedly be inserted anywhere in the universe and set up a radio and get in touch with someone thousands of miles away if we had to be resupplied or whatever.
But the other part had to do with a very important part of the mission of Special Forces.
Well, the overall mission of Special Forces is to train and equip the indigenous personnel in the art of guerrilla warfare.
In Vietnam, the mission was to train and equip the indigenous personnel in the art of counterinsurgency.
But this idea of training is a very important part of the mission of Special Forces.
So we had a big unit as part of our training on teaching, where we learned about visual aids and how to give a speech and how to teach and how to test and all that sort of stuff.
So as I recall, phase one involved learning our job specialization and also learning how to teach maybe some other stuff.
I can't recall.
And then that was tactics and techniques phase one.
And then tactics and techniques phase two involved actual

you know, learning about guerrilla warfare, how to conduct both insurgent and counterinsurgent, counterinsurgency operations, which involved, you know, setting up camps and, you know, all your basic infantry kinds of tactics, how to put together a mission, how to make what they called poncho parachutes, how to build
landing zones, how to build drop zones so you could be resupplied from the air.
In fact, one part of that training involved going out somewhere and building.
I think the engineers built a runway, and then they had C-130s come and pick us up.
And then the engineers had also built a drop zone, and then they dropped us in on the drop zone.
And then the last part of the
Phase two is where you got together in a team, a 12-man team.
They put you in what they called kind of a safe house situation, where you're isolated from the world.
You planned a mission that you were going to go on, and then you executed the mission.
In our case, we got dropped into Pisgah, North Carolina National Forest at night in a soybean field, and we were picked up by

indigenous people that's farmers and stuff and pick up trucks and they cover us over and drove us in the mountains and we conducted more or less a guerrilla campaign while at the same time being pursued by counter-insurgents pretty good training when you got out of uh your training what what happened then i was assigned to vietnam no i was assigned to the seventh special forces group company a
I was there on what they called, I can't remember the actual name of it, but I was attached to a special project at that time that I'm not at liberty to discuss, even to this very day.
Top secret.
Well, I don't know, whatever you want to call it, but I was assigned to the special project for approximately seven months, and then after that I was...
assigned to the Special Forces in Vietnam.
When you got your orders to go overseas, what were your feelings?
Were you scared?
Well, I saw guys going all the time, you know, so I figured, well, sort of, yeah.
At this point, I was kind of, you know, wary.
I was thinking, oh, geez, you know, this is it.
what we called at that time the Live Fire FTX.
FTX stands for Field Training Exercise.
Whenever everybody got their orders to go to Vietnam, they called it the Live Fire FTX.
You were on your way to Vietnam.
And there weren't a whole lot of guys at that time either that had, younger guys that had been to Vietnam and then come back and were reassigned to a stateside unit.
But
So, they didn't really have a lot of guys to talk to who had been there.
The older NCOs had got some of them, and a lot of the older NCOs, as a matter of fact, went over there and stayed.
I mean, a lot of them had been over there since the late 50s, you know.
So, there wasn't a pool of guys, really, you know, that you could talk to and find out a whole lot about it from.
So, yeah, I was worried, but I wasn't scared.
I was just worried.
you know, concerned, but I felt equipped.
You know, I felt like I was really well-trained.
Did you feel like one of the best and the brightest?
Oh, yeah.
I felt like I had had the best possible training, at least in the Army, you know, that you could get.
And the kind of mission, you know, that I perceived of myself performing in Vietnam was precisely, you know, what I wanted to do.
When you first got to Vietnam,
What did you see?
Let's see.
I saw a Tan Sanute Air Force base.
No, no, not Tan Sanute.
Cameron Bay.
Got off the plane and looked around.
It looked like a giant prison camp.
There was barbed wire all over the place.
There was nobody wearing anything but military uniforms.
They rushed us off the plane, jumped onto a bus,
took us somewhere, immediately separated the Special Forces guys out, put everybody else in a big lump.
And then they had, for the officers, for the Special Forces officers, they had helicopters, came and picked them up and took them off to Natrang.
And then the enlisted guys, they gave us all M-16s, put us on trucks, and drove us to Natrang from Cam Ranh Bay.
Where is that train?
I guess it's about 125 miles north of Cam Ranh Bay.
That was strange.
I mean, we rode down these roads at, you know, 60 miles an hour, and the Montagnards were driving the trucks, these wild ass, you know, little people from the mountains.
And we just went roar assing through all these little villages.
locked and loaded.
I'll never forget when I finally got to the train, my ass hurt so bad.
I couldn't sit down.
I couldn't sit down for a week.
But that was my initial experience, right?
You know, here's a gun, go to the train.
You set up as a radio operator there, right?
You were in charge of more or less the communications organization period.
What they call first echelon maintenance and, you know, teaching the people that we worked with, you know, appropriate radio procedure and that sort of stuff.
Did you have a lot of Vietnamese help with your operations?
Not really, no.
Vietnamese counterparts.
See, at that time, there was some controversy.
They had the Mike Force, which was what I was in.
We had Montagnard mercenaries, more or less.
These guys were paid.
They weren't a part of the, we were attached to the Vietnamese Army.
We weren't a part of the United States Army when we were there.
So all our equipment came through the Vietnamese Army.
But we were supposed to have what they call Vietnamese counterparts.

And at this time, there was sort of like an internal rebellion among the Montagnards, and they all threatened to quit and go back to Bamituot, where most of them came from, or at least the ones that we had.
And there had been some rebellions at some of the egg camps.
they had one of the camps they had held, you know, taking the Vietnamese and strung them up from the, you know, the flag poles, and it held the Americans not really hostage.
But anyway, the Moniards hated all Vietnamese.
So at the time when I got there, they had sort of shuffled the Vietnamese off to Buffalo for a while, you know, until things cooled down.
But the Moniards just created a ruckus.
We were in
bad shape for a while because half of them just said, screw you, you know, and took their portable radios and headed back to the mountains.
Back to the mountains.
Yeah.

You had problems with the mountain yards, and from what we've been studying in history, it seems like a lot of times U.S. troops didn't know exactly who to fight, but with the Viet Cong in the south and the Viet Minh in the north.
Did you ever get that feeling of
who are we here against?
Well, only with reference to the Vietnamese, you know.

The Montagnards were pretty, they, like I said, they hated all Vietnamese, and they were perfect, you know, perfect allies, and the Vietnamese hated the Cambodians, you know, so, so we had Special Forces basically had Cambodian strike force teams, Cambodian mercenaries and Montagnard mercenaries,
the idea being that these guys hated Vietnamese, and they didn't give a damn whether they were Viet Cong, North Vietnamese, South Vietnamese, or anything.
They hated Vietnamese.
So, with reference to the people that we worked most closely with, nah, not really.
But see, there was, it was just pretty strange.
I mean, yeah,
I mean, when you go into a village or ride by people or whatever, you never know what the hell their proclivities were.
So, you know, it kind of, you never know.
That's it.
Bottom line.
Nobody.
Nobody Vietnamese.
But the Montagnards are pretty trustworthy little guys, I think.
And I think they're probably still fighting to this very day.
I wouldn't doubt it one bit.
People tend to fight a long time if they want something that bad.
On a geographic level, what was Vietnam like?
I've heard it was all jungle, mountainous.
See, I spent most of my time out in the terrain.
And we traveled around a lot as part of what we had to do.
But where I was, it was a lot like Southern California.
I mean, what blew me away, well, I came back from Vietnam one time on an emergency leave to escort a body back, and I landed.
I'd never been to California before.
I think it was Travis Air Force Base in California that we landed at.
I'm not sure, though.
But I got off the plane.
I looked around.
I said, God damn.
This looks exactly like where I am.
This is all flying and leaving from this place.
Right.
So we were on the beach.
I mean, it was beautiful.
Sandy beaches.
You looked out from where we were.
Our little detachment was right on the edge of what they called the SFOP, which is the Special Forces Operational Base.
It's like the main home base for Special Forces.
And we were out on one edge.
And you could look out.
There's a big open field and a beautiful mountain, just like you see in California, where if you're on the coast and you see the ocean, and you look over your shoulder, there's the mountains.
You couldn't see the ocean exactly from where we were, but it was a lot like California, you know.
That's interesting.
Yeah.
Had a rainy season like you have in California.
What, aside from military activities, went on in Vietnam?
For me, basically drinking and whoring, I guess you'd say.
I mean, extracurricular activities.
But everybody had their own quirks, you know.
I mean, there were religious guys right alongside of the, you know, the profane, sinful-type guys.

Whenever we had spare time, we would either go into the trang itself, or if we were on a long stand-down, I'd go travel, see my buddies, you know, at other camps, especially up at Pleiku, where I had a really, really close friend.
In the movies, you see all this drug abuse going on in the military in Vietnam, the troops walking through the swamp smoking a joint.
I don't put much stock in that, but mainly because it's Hollywood.
But was drug abuse, right in the middle of the 60s, drugs were starting to be the end thing.
Was drug abuse very prevalent in the military in Vietnam?
From my experience, toward the end of my stay there, the guys that started coming in from the States were using marijuana, you know, like into marijuana, you know.
And on a couple of occasions, I got hooked up with some real loony bins guys.
And I remember one time going to an opium den.
I didn't smoke any opium.
I was just shocked.
I mean, here I was, you know, roasting 12 Special Forces, but I never thought
that there was such a thing in the world as these places where people laid on wooden beds and huffed on opium.
I remember, too, when I was there, I went in and looked around and said, this is fucking crazy.
I don't have anything to do with this.
So I sat out in the waiting room with the woman that was running the place.
And while I was there, what amounted to the Vietnamese pusher man came around
And I'll never forget, man, he had this big black briefcase, right?
And he dumped it out on the floor, and it was just all, like, already rolled marijuana cigarettes.
And he and this woman haggled over these things for about 20 minutes while I was sitting there drinking, you know, and watching them.
It was weird.
And then when this one guy, these guys that I was with, whose names I'll never remember, uh,
When they went back out onto the street, man, everybody that saw them, all the Vietnamese that saw them were going, you know, they could tell, look at these guys, and they were just bongo.

But most of the guys that I knew, there was kind of like a, see, Special Forces, you know, it wasn't really, I mean, everybody in Special Forces wasn't Special Forces trained, and there were all sorts of what you would call sort of support personnel who were,
who didn't have the same ideals, you know, and ambitions of the guys that had actually gone through the training.

And you'd meet some of these guys in the train, you know, who were in headquarters company, and these guys were the ones that were sort of like, you know, not up to standards, I guess you might say, or up to speed.
There were a lot of guys wearing berets over there that didn't even have, had never been to airborne school or anything.
were assigned to special forces, you know, cooks, you name it.
So that's one thing a lot of people don't realize when they look, you know, think about special forces.
There were guys over there that were involved in intelligence work and things.
I never realized that there were so many people that weren't trained in special forces.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah, and at the time I was there, they were hurting for people, so they would take guys from, you know, like the 101st Airborne
See, once you got there, and if you had some combat experience, you could volunteer to go into Special Forces.
So we had a lot of guys that would come in.
Not a lot, but a few, who had been in the 101st, and maybe had decided to stay in Vietnam for an extra year.
And part of the condition of the re-enlistment was to get into Special Forces.
Because actually, Special Forces duty was pretty good stuff.
At least it was for me.

this all this drug questions i asked or leading to one point to me the other day or a couple of months ago she said that she thought that one of the reasons for our i guess you could say failure to win the war in vietnam was because a lot of people were coming out of high school and not having the opportunity to go to college like yourself and that a lot of them
were not the caliber of men we would want serving our country.
Would you buy that argument at all?
Well, I don't know.
Most of the guys that I spent any time with were excellent human beings, some of the best people that I have or ever will.
